title: 104_s1688
content: The "Rural Law Enforcement Act of 1996" may be cited as the official title. Key findings are outlined in the Act. The Congress recognizes the importance of effective law enforcement, especially in rural areas where a significant portion of Americans reside. Rural violent crime has been on the rise, impacting both citizens and law enforcement agencies. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock collaborates with the FBI and DOJ to provide training and education programs for rural law enforcement agencies. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to establish the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement is established at the University of Arkansas, Little Rock, with an Advisory Board comprised of 15 members selected by the Attorney General of the United States, in consultation with the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, from rural law enforcement agencies serving communities with populations of less than 25,000 people. The Advisory Board for the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement is comprised of 15 members selected by the Attorney General and the Director of the FBI. Members serve for 1 year terms with 3 rotating each year, and they formulate guidelines for the center's operation. The Advisory Board for the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement formulates guidelines for the center's operation. The Executive Director is appointed by the Attorney General in consultation with the FBI Director and the Chancellor of the University of Arkansas at Little Rock for a term of up to 5 years. Members of the Advisory Board are allowed travel expenses while performing services. The Executive Director of the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement has duties outlined in the Act, including reporting to the Advisory Board and the Chancellor of the University of Arkansas at Little Rock. The Center may procure temporary services with approval from the Advisory Board at specified rates. The Executive Director of the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement has duties outlined in the Act, including reporting to the Advisory Board and the Chancellor of the University of Arkansas at Little Rock. The Center may procure temporary services with approval from the Advisory Board at specified rates. SEC. 180402. FUNCTIONS. The Director of the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement is responsible for training, supporting, and providing education opportunities for rural law enforcement agencies. This includes delivering training programs, promoting national education standards, and disseminating information to assist states and local governments in rural areas. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement provides grants, contracts, and assistance to Federal, State, and local agencies for the development and coordination of programs, training, research, and prevention of crime in rural areas. They also establish a clearinghouse for information on criminal justice and law enforcement. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement focuses on providing assistance and support to government programs, law enforcement officers, and other personnel in rural areas. They also conduct research, develop training programs, and formulate policies to address criminal activity in rural communities. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement focuses on providing assistance, support, research, training programs, and policies for rural law enforcement agencies. They evaluate new approaches and techniques to improve rural law enforcement systems. The Center has the authority to enter contracts, cooperative agreements, and arrange reimbursements with public or private agencies for their functions. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement can collaborate with departments, agencies, state and local governments, and experts for assistance. They can also utilize consensus building and work cooperatively with others in carrying out their functions. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement can collaborate with various entities, request necessary materials from other departments, reimburse for the use of resources, and utilize assistance from State and local governments or other organizations. The National Center for Rural Law Enforcement can collaborate with State and local governments, agencies, organizations, and individuals. Authorization of appropriations for the National Center for Rural Law Enforcement includes $12,000,000 for fiscal year 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1998 through 2001.
